docs.title: Welcome to Ramsey Docs
docs.text:
Hi guys!

Documentation is one of the most important steps when learning or working. There are many tools available to help us manage our notes effectively.

Today, I want to introduce another way to organize your notes: Markdown.

docs.title: Some flag in command
docs.text:
-d: run in "detached" mode
-i: keep STDIN open 
-t: allocate a terminal interating with container
-it: access terminal
--name: name
-p: map ports
--rm: remove the container when it exits.
-v: mout a volume
--network: specify the network (Default: bridge)
-e: environment variables
--link: link to another running container
--restart: set the restart policy

docs.title: List images
docs.text:
$ docker image ls
or
$ docker images

docs.title: Some sample container creation
docs.text:
NGINX:

$ docker container run -d -p 80:80 --name nginx nginx

APACHE:

$ docker container run -d -p 8080:80 --name apache httpd

MONGODB:

$ docker container run -d -p 27017:27017 --name mongo mongo

MYSQL:

$ docker container run -d -p 3306:3306 --name mysql --env MYSQL_ROOT_PASSWORD=123456 mysql

docs.title: TIP: About containers
docs.text: Docker containers are often compared to virtual machines but they are actually just processes running on your host os. In Windows/Mac, Docker runs in a mini-VM so to see the processes youll need to connect directly to that. On Linux however you can run "ps aux" and see the processes directly

docs.title: Create network
docs.text:
$ docker network create [NETWORK_NAME]

or 

$ docker network create --driver bridge [NETWORK_NAME]

docs.title: Delete/Remove network
docs.text:
To remove the network by name or id, multiple can be deleted:

$ docker network rm [NETWORK_NAME] [NETWORK_NAME]

docs.title: Volumes
docs.text: Volume - Makes special location outside of container UFS. Used for databases Bind Mount -Link container path to host path

docs.title: TIP: Mounts
docs.text:
• You will also see the volume under mounts
  • Container gets its own uniqe location on the host to store that data
  • Source: xxx is where it lives on the host

docs.title: Check volumes
docs.text:
$ docker volume ls

There is no way to tell volumes apart for instance with 2 mysql containers, so we used named volumes

docs.title: Named volumes (Add -v command)
docs.text: $ docker container run -d --name mysql -v mysql-db:/var/lib/mysql mysql

docs.title: Dockerfile path
docs.text:
• FROM - The os used. Common is alpine, debian, ubuntu
  • ENV - Environment variables
  • RUN - Run commands/shell scripts, etc
  • EXPOSE - Ports to expose
  • CMD - Final command run when you launch a new container from image
  • WORKDIR - Sets working directory (also could use 'RUN cd /some/path')
  • COPY # Copies files from host to container

docs.title: From the same directory as Dockerfile
Tip: Cache and Order
docs.text:
• If you re-run the build, it will be quick because everythging is cached.
  • If you change one line and re-run, that line and everything after will not be cached
  • Keep things that change the most toward the bottom of the Dockerfile

docs.title: Usual step
docs.text:
Build image from Dockerfile

$ docker image build -t nginx
Running it

$ docker container run -p 80:80 --rm nginx
Tag 

$ docker image tag nginx:latest ramseytrinh/nginx:latest
Push to Dockerhub 
$ docker image push ramseytrinh/nginx:latest

docs.title: DOCKER COMPOSE
docs.text:
• Configure relationships between containers
  • Save our docker container run settings in easy to read file

docs.title: Sample compose file
docs.text:
version: '2'

# same as
# docker run -p 80:4000 -v $(pwd):/site bretfisher/jekyll-serve

services:
  jekyll:
    image: bretfisher/jekyll-serve
    volumes:
      - .:/site
    ports:
      - '80:4000'

docs.title: Example 2
docs.text:
version: '3'
services:
  app:
    container_name: docker-node-mongo
    restart: always
    build: .
    ports:
      - '80:3000'
    links:
      - mongo
  mongo:
    container_name: mongo
    image: mongo
    ports:
      - '27017:27017'

docs.title: You can run in background with
How to run fci bss portal
Run portal-bss-api
docs.text: Recommended to use Ubuntu or WSL to run Portal-bss-api

docs.title: Setup Kong Gateway
docs.text:
Change docker-compose.yml: 

# Change image
quay.io/keycloak/keycloak:16.1.1
# command this line
command: --default-authentication-plugin=mysql_native_password
Change kong.yml: 
WSL

cp kong_template.yml kong.yml
# in kong.yml
# command service API internal
# command service TERRAFORM 
# command plugins
Run docker compose 
WSL

set KONG_TARGET_SVC_ADDR="host.docker.internal"
sed -i 's/{KONG_TARGET_SVC_ADDR}/'"$KONG_TARGET_SVC_ADDR"'/g' kong.yml

```bash
CMD
# Start DB first as some some services may fail to access DB early

docker-compose up -d db
sleep 5
docker-compose up -d

# Check if container DB is running or not
# If not, try to delete volumn of the container

docs.title: Import Database
docs.text:
After run container successfully, go to localhost:8002

  • Go to Keycloak admin portal (localhost:8002, account admin/abc123)
  • Import 3 file sql to dtb: keycloak, user, iaas-vmw
